title: Bootstrap tabs not loading jQuery & Ajax
body:
I have a tab pane using Bootstrap that I am attempting to load external pages into using Ajax via a jQuery script.

The ajax script is loading the pages' contents, however, the panes are not switching properly. They will load when I click on them, but they just "stick around," with the 2nd one stacking below the 1st pane when I click on it.

Here is the HTML (note, I am using Django, so the hrefs are Django lookups)

<div class="container-fluid">
    <div id="tabs">
        <ul class="nav nav-tabs" id="caseTab">
            <li class="active">
                <a data-url="{% url 'person_case_list' person.id %}" href="#case_list">Case List</a>
            </li>
            <li>
                <a data-url="{% url 'pledge_list' person.id %}" href="#pledge_list">Pledge List</a>
            </li>
        </ul>
        <div class="tab-content">

            <div class="tab-pane active" id="case_list">

            </div>

            <div class="tab-pane active" id="pledge_list">

            </div>

        </div>
    </div>
</div>

The javascript is:

<script>
$('#caseTab a').click(function (e) {
    var url = $(this).attr("data-url");
    console.log(url);

    if(typeof url !== "undefined") {
        var pane = $(this), href = this.hash;

comments.body: toFixed() returns a string and strings don't have a toFixed() method.

You have type confusion. toFixed returns a string, so your number variable starts out as a number and becomes a string after increase or decrease. Separate the state from the display (number += 0.1; console.log('Number: ', number.toFixed(1));).
But why the decreasing is working every time? Even if toFixed(1) returns a string
Subtraction only works on numbers, so it’ll convert the string, but + doubles as the string concatenation operator and converts the number.
@CommercialSuicide JavaScript automatically converts it from the -, where the + is interpreted as string concatenation.
Because + is overloaded to act on strings, but - is not.

answers.title: Can't increase by 0.1 with `toFixed(1)` in JavaScript
answers.body:
The toFixed() method returns a string type, and string don't have a toFixed() method - resulting in the error of .toFixed is not a function.

To resolve, force the output from toFixed() back to a number. This can be done with Number() or the shorthand method of prepending +.

  • Number((0.1).toFixed())
  • +(0.1).toFixed()

var number = 0.5;
console.log('Number: ', number)

function increase() {
  if (number < 1) {
    number = Number((number + 0.1).toFixed(1));
    console.log('Number: ', number)
  }
}

function decrease() {
  if (number > 0) {
    number = Number((number - 0.1).toFixed(1));
    console.log('Number: ', number)
  }
}
<button onclick="increase()">Increase</button>
<button onclick="decrease()">Decrease</button>

comments.body: parseFloat seems to work too, thanks for your answer!

answers.title: Can't increase by 0.1 with `toFixed(1)` in JavaScript
answers.body:
The return value of toFixed method is a string, as mentioned in MDN web docs:

Return value: A string representing the given number using fixed-point notation.

So, when calling increase or decrease for the first time, the value of the variable number will be of type string.

After that when calling increase:

number + 0.1 will be of type string, because string + number is a string, and toFixed is not a function of strings, and that's why you get the error:

Uncaught TypeError: (number + 0.1).toFixed is not a function

However, number - 0.1 will work, because string - number is a number and that's fine.

To solve this, you should keep your number of type number, and you can do this in multiple ways:

  • Use the method parseFloat():

number = parseFloat((number + 0.1).toFixed(1));

  • Use Number object constructor:

number = Number((number + 0.1).toFixed(1));

  • Use +:

number = +((number + 0.1).toFixed(1));

answers.title: Node child process spawn output is different than from terminal
answers.body:
There are a couple of differences.

It could be that you're missing things on stderr (sh.stderr.on('data', ...)).

The other possibility, especially if it is a progress bar-like thing which is rewriting the line, then console.log() won't be able to do that.

How those progress bars work is they use a combination of process.stdout.write() and, process.stdout.cursorTo() and process.stdout.clearLine(), which actually lets them erase and rewrite a line. Putting that through console.log from data will output very differently.

answers.title: node: mocking a function with a callback argument
answers.body:
This is not straightforward in testing because it involved callbacks. You need to test wether a callback you passed to readFile was called with right arguments, which in this case is the dummyFile.

    import sinon from 'sinon'
    import jsonfile from './jsonfile'

    const jsonFileMock = sinon.spy(jsonfile, 'readFile');
    const callback = sinon.spy();

    jsonfile.readFile(callback);
    jsonFileMock.callsArgWith(1, 'dummyFileName');

    expect(callback.calledWith('dummyFileName')).to.be.true;
    jsonFileMock.restore();

If you want to abstract this into a function, than it can be something like : 

function mock(module, method, ...callbacks){
  const stub = sinon.stub(jsonfile, 'readFile');
  callbacks.forEach((callback, index) => {
    stub.callsArgWith(index, callback);
  });
}

answers.title: node: mocking a function with a callback argument
answers.body:
But actually, why don't you just replace readFile by a function with the same definition (so that it doesn't break the code using it). And just return your mock data.

jsonfile.readFile = function(filePath, callback) {
    callback(null, { mockData: "foo" });
};

easy as that.

Otherwise, you can use a Proxy if you don't want to deal with the definition : 

const jsonfile = {
    readFile: function(filename, callback) {
        callback();
    }
};

// intercept every call to readFile and always return the mock data
jsonfile.readFile = new Proxy(jsonfile.readFile, {
    apply: function(target, thisArg, args) {
        return args[1](null, { someMocking: "" });
    }
});

// call readFile as usual
jsonfile.readFile('testfile', function(err, result) {
    console.log(result);
});

Proxies work as interceptors.

https://developer.mozilla.org/fr/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Objets_globaux/Proxy

comments.body: Use typeecript, it provides syntactic sugar for the things you are referring to. Typescript also provides optional type checking at compilation time

I'm not actually a huge fan of using instanceof. Basically it violates Liskov's principle which states: "if a program module is using a Base class, then the reference to the Base class can be replaced with a Derived class without affecting the functionality of the program module". Usually, if you are using instanceof, it implies that the two subclasses of the abstract classes could not substitute the abstract class.
This is true for pure OOP languages. However, instanceof is still very useful in JavaScript, which is often used as a functional one.

answers.title: What is the best way to achieve the behavior of abstract methods from OOP languages in Javascript (es6)?
answers.body:
The first option throwing exceptions is, IMO, much better.

The first reason I think about is:

function createCat() {
  return new Animal(() => 'meow');
}

createCat() instanceof Cat // This line is pointless, cat does not even exist.

But if you use:

class Cat extends Animal {
  cry() {
    return 'meow';
  }
}

new Cat() instanceof Cat // true
new Cat() instanceof Animal // true

You have a feature you wouldn't have by using the former.

Edit: you could do a mixture of these two by doing something like this (I didn't check if the code is correct):

function factoryAnimal(ctror) {
  const r = () => {
    ctor.prototype = Object.create(Animal);
    const res = new Animal(ctror);
    res.__proto__ = ctror.prototype;
    return res;
  }
  return r;
}

function Cat() {
  return "meow";
}

const createCat = factoryAnimal(Cat);

createCat() instanceof Cat // This should work returning true.

title: What is the best way to achieve the behavior of abstract methods from OOP languages in Javascript (es6)?
body:
I am programming in Javascript (es6) while coming in from a Java background. In Java, I commonly write interfaces/abstract classes and this feature is lacking in es6. Commonly, I like writing abstract methods in order to use design patterns, such as the Strategy Pattern. I have seen others try to implement their own version of abstract classes, but I am not particularly fond of it.

Suppose that we have an abstract class called Animal and it has an abstract method cry. From what I have been seeing, the Javascript code would look like:

class Animal {
  constructor() {
   if (new.target === Animal) {
    throw new TypeError("Cannot construct Animal instances directly");
   }
  }

  cry() {
    throw new Error('You have to implement the method cry!');
  }
}

And let's say that Cat and Dog are subclasses of Animal. Then, their implementation would look like the following:

class Cat extends Animal {
  cry() {
    return 'meow';
  }
}

class Dog extends Animal {
  cry() {
    return 'woof';
  }
}

What I don't like about this code is that you have to write exception statements to indicate that a class is an abstract class.

However, I think that there is a better approach using callbacks and factory methods. Instead of having abstract methods for an abstract class, we can pass in a callback function into the abstract class and use that as our supposed abstract method. The Animal example can be changed to the following:

class Animal {
  constructor(cryCallback) {
    this.cryCallback = cryCallback;
  }

  cry() {
    return this.cryCallback();
  }
}

In order to create instances of a Cat and a Dog object, you can basically create them with a factory method. It would look like the following:

function createCat() {
  return new Animal(() => 'meow');
}

function createDog() {
  return new Animal(() => 'woof');
}

If you create a Cat instance and call cry, it would look like the following:

console.log(createCat().cry()); //meow

The advantages of using this approach are that you are not actually calling an instance of Animal because you are forced to implement cry. Second, you can hide the implementation of creating a Cat or Dog object with the factory method.

Please let me know what you think about this approach. Are there better approaches to achieve abstract methods in Javascript?

Yes, it is what I thought. I notice if setting date as new Date('September 27, 2017') there is no issues, and both had same amount of information. Is this a javascript bug?

Not a bug, just inconsistency, using "YYYY-MM-DD" format it assumes UTC timezone (which is then converted to your local timezone where the day doesn't match), while giving "Month DD, YYYY" uses your local timezone. developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/…

answers.title: JavaScript two equal Date with different day
answers.body:
The reason is when you pass the date 2017-09-27 into the date method you have not passed a timezone in. Look at the results below:

> new Date()
Wed Sep 27 2017 12:58:39 GMT-0700 (PDT)
> new Date('2017-09-27')
Tue Sep 26 2017 17:00:00 GMT-0700 (PDT)

You can pass your time zone in for example in PDT (GMT-08:00)

> new Date('2017-09-27 GMT-08:00')
Wed Sep 27 2017 01:00:00 GMT-0700 (PDT)

Or you can use a library like moment.

answers.title: Dynatable - features is undefined
answers.body:
A console.log of the dyna variable shows the following:

{   
    $element: [table#dyno-table, context: table#dyno-table]
    dom: Dom {update: ƒ}
    domColumns:DomColumns {initOnLoad: ƒ, init: ƒ, getFromTable: ƒ, add: ƒ, remove: ƒ, …}
    element : table#dyno-table
    inputsSearch : InputsSearch {initOnLoad: ƒ, init: ƒ, create: ƒ, attach: ƒ}
    paginationLinks : PaginationLinks {initOnLoad: ƒ, init: ƒ, create: ƒ, buildLink: ƒ, attach: ƒ}
    paginationPage : PaginationPage {initOnLoad: ƒ, init: ƒ, set: ƒ}
    paginationPerPage : PaginationPerPage {initOnLoad: ƒ, init: ƒ, create: ƒ, attach: ƒ, set: ƒ}
    processingIndicator : ProcessingIndicator {init: ƒ, create: ƒ, position: ƒ, attach: ƒ, show: ƒ, …}
    queries : Queries {initOnLoad: ƒ, init: ƒ, add: ƒ, remove: ƒ, run: ƒ, …}
    records : Records {initOnLoad: ƒ, init: ƒ, updateFromJson: ƒ, sort: ƒ, paginate: ƒ, …}
    recordsCount : RecordsCount {initOnLoad: ƒ, init: ƒ, create: ƒ, attach: ƒ}
    settings : {features: {…}, table: {…}, inputs: {…}, dataset: {…}, writers: {…}, …}
    sorts : Sorts {initOnLoad: ƒ, init: ƒ, add: ƒ, remove: ƒ, clear: ƒ, …}
    sortsHeaders : SortsHeaders {initOnLoad: ƒ, init: ƒ, create: ƒ, removeAll: ƒ, removeOne: ƒ, …}
    state : State {initOnLoad: ƒ, init: ƒ, push: ƒ, pop: ƒ}
    __proto__ : Object
}

This is the output in the Chrome Dev tools formatted nicely to show what the object key names are. As you can see, there is no direct access to features through the top level object. It is, however, inside settings.

So dyna.features is undefined

but

dyna.settings.features is an object which is probably what you are looking for.

So you just need to change the following lines from:

dyna.features.paginate.recordCount = false;
dyna.features.paginate.perPageSelect = false;

to

dyna.settings.features.paginate.recordCount = false;
dyna.settings.features.paginate.perPageSelect = false;

Update

Actually, I am not sure what you are trying to do but the above example will prevent the error but it may not get you the desired results. If your intention was to disable pagination and record counting then it won't work. You have to define those features on initialization. You can do this by adding in a features object with some properties like so:

// ...previous code
dyna = $('#product-table').dynatable({
    dataset: {
        records: data
    },
    features: {
        recordCount: false,
        perPageSelect: false,
    }
}).data('dynatable');
//... after code

answers.body:
You are incorrectly trying to execute code in the returned object definition.

Pull that firebase call out of the data method object, and call it in the created lifecycle hook (referencing the office array via this.office):

data() {
  return {
    office: []
  }
},
created() {
  firebase.database().ref('employees').on('value').then((data) => {
    this.office.push(data);
  }).catch((error) => {
    console.log(error);
  });
}

answers.title: JavaScript+Mocha+Chai. Why do my test always pass?
answers.body:
You need to declare done as an argument to it.

it('Does x', (done) => {
  someAsyncFunc((err, result) => {
    done()
  })
})

By declaring that 1st argument you essentially tell mocha to wait until done is called, otherwise it just considers it a synchronous test

Therefore it won't wait for your expect calls to run and will prematurely consider the test as succesful.

From Mocha's docs:

Simply invoke the callback when your test is complete. By adding a callback (usually named done) to it(), Mocha will know that it should wait for this function to be called to complete the test.

answers.title: Why is selector.text getting an internal function value?
answers.body:
jQuery's text() is a function, not a property, to be used as $("#status").text("Refreshing");

It does however accept a callback you can use for concatenating text, like this

var notice = $("#status");
notice.text(function(_,txt) {
    return txt + "."
});

When you do notice.text(notice.text + "."); you're trying to add a period to a function reference

comments.body: There is no such thing as a "class variable" in JS. You most likely want an instance property, which is created and accessed with this.. See the duplicate on what to do about "this not [being] defined" in the callback.
Notice that you don't want to do asynchronous things in your constructor anyway (no matter whether with promises or async.js)

comments.body: Try using docs.hyper.sh/Reference/API/2016-04-04%20[Ver.%201.23]/… with follow=1, this api should finish when the container finishes. Or you can use attach with stream=1 and stdout=1 docs.hyper.sh/Reference/API/2016-04-04%20[Ver.%201.23]/…. That also should finish when the container finishes. So both (assuming they work) are smarter then the existing approach.

title: How to retrieve a file from Hyper.sh container?
body:
We are using hyper.sh to test JavaScript exams. The call to the hyper.sh API creates a container that uses a bash script to clone the submission, install dependencies, and pipe test results to /tmp/student_results.

Previously, we utilized dockerode in this process and were able to call getArchive as part of a callback provided to container.run(). The Hyper.sh CLI doesn't have the ability to provide a callback or to get file archives it seems.

We can echo the file contents to stdout and retrieve the logs from the hyper containers, but we don't have a way to know when the process is done. The hyper CLI lets you wait for a container to finish but the API does not.

Our current solution for this problem would be to curl the contents of the file to a webhook in our application. Is there a smarter way?

answers.title: jQuery does not work for navbar in Materialize CSS
answers.body:
The problem is the address jQuery went to for the loading.

$("#nav-wrapper").load("untitled2/navbar.html");
Change this code this way.

$("#nav-wrapper").load("../untitled2/navbar.html");

comments.body: Which version and build number of Outlook are you getting this on?

Outlook Client is Version 1708 (Build 8431.2079 Click to Run) The Exchange Server is 2013 not sure the build number on that or if it makes a difference, using version "@microsoft/office-js-helpers": "^0.7.4",
Host Version: 15.0.1293.4
Are you referencing a local copy of office.js or from the cdn?
Both appsforoffice.microsoft.com/lib/1.1/hosted/office.debug.js

You should only reference it once: <script src="https://appsforoffice.microsoft.com/lib/1/hosted/Office‌​.js" type="text/javascript"></script> is the correct location. If you want the debug version (although I've never needed it myself), use https://appsforoffice.microsoft.com/lib/1/hosted/Office.debu‌​g.js

I just created a new project using VS2017 Outlook Web Add-in in the messageRead.js I pasted. Office.context.ui.displayDialogAsync('dev.office.com'); right above the line of code that reads $(document).ready(function () { Put dev.office.com in my App Domain list and ran it same error.

I wouldn't expect that to work. First because you're not referencing a page within your add-in so it doesn't have an Office.initialize(), second because it need to be a full HTTPS URL (https://dev.office.com). It also should go after $(document).ready so your DOM has time to load (although I don't think that is a problem here).

Also, the error you're getting here isn't actually with displayDialogAsync. Note that is says 'displayDialogAsync' of undefined. If you break on that line, you should be able to determine which object isn't defined (Office, context, ui).
It is wrapped by the initialize, the start of VS2017 is Office.initialize then $(document) I put the line of code between the 2. Office.context.ui.displayDialogAsync('dev.office.com');
Entire line of code Office.initialize = function (reason) { Office.context.ui.displayDialogAsync('dev.office.com'); };

@MarcLaFleur-MSFT in my case the UI object is not defined (Office and Context are). Do you have any suggestions why could this be happening? I am building a React App for Outlook web application. My code is inside Office.initialize.
If ui isn't defined, I suspect your loading a local (older) version of office.js. I would start by making sure there are no references to local or debug versions of the library.
